Ga9HSghCrvOHre4kaJ9p1Q.text: Holy f'ing shit. This restaurant, hands down, changed my entire attitude/palate towards Indian food. I've had LOTS of Indian food that was ... okay. It was edible. Nothing major. Nothing that made me say "now THAT was some good shit!". But after having dinner with my husband at Indian City last week I can honestly say that I've had the best Indian I've ever eaten. We shared an order of garlic naan and onion bhajees to start- the bhajees are things dreams are made of. I NEED to figure out how to make them at home. For my entree I ordered the chicken joypuri. Inhaled. It. Amazingly good. I really can't wait to try everything else on the menu, however, seeing as I'm in Indiana, it'll be kinda hard... and I'm going to be CRAVING Indian City!

Whp-aA3UmmkWBCt9TRbccg.text: We ate at this Indian restaurant while on vacation in London. It was decent and the staff was friendly.

HerSrh5FZ5J3f5z0QKlbyA.text: Quick review:+ set menu for lunch - good value+ speedy service+ friendly staff+ lots of space- a bit dark for interiorI came here on a Friday lunch time with a colleague, after we walked away from two nearby Chinese restaurants due to long queues. We were a bit worried how empty it looked in Indian City on Friday lunch timebut decided to give a try anyway. The entryway is narrow and we walked past a few tables through to the back of the restaurant which has more space. The set menu is pretty good value, under £7 for a main, or just under £9 for a starter and main. We ordered from the express lunch menu and the food arrived very quickly, which is great for those who may want hot food but hasn't got hours for a sit down lunch. The food was very tasty and the portion size was small, compared to other Indian restaurants I've been to, but it's plenty of food for lunch especially for the value. i also liked that the restaurant does not automatically add service charge on top of the bill. The only downside is that it feels pretty dark inside, but it doesn't detract from the service nor the food. The staff is friendly and held the doors for us, with genuine smiles, as we exited the restaurant. I will definitely come back when I'm feeling particularly hungry for a work lunch!

9qigehgwHfQtbqC2sCs6_Q.text: This place was very disappointing. Atmosphere is nice, and the staff was pretty good, but the food itself was average or below. Unfortunately the price was above average, which made for a very out-of-whack sense of value.  Over 3 quid just for a tiny bowl of rice!  I don't mind spending money on a nice dinner, but such prices on rubbish is a very bad experience.  There are hundreds of good Indian restaurants in London, so no need to waste time or money on this one.

YdYJMrKEPxcQgIjbLuhmEA.text: I have never been to a place that flat out lied and refused to serve us.  We are here for a family trip and had a very long day (spent 4 hours in traffic!).  We wanted Indian food and this place had pretty good reviews so we gave it a shot.  When we walked up, the waiter met us outside, saw we had a 16 month old and immediately said they have no tables.  We saw multiple open tables but he said they are all reserved (at 9pm on a Sunday) and the only option is takeaway.  Look, if you don't want to have a kid in your restaurant, I get that, just tell us and we will be on our way.  But to lie without hesitation right to our face is just rude.  What a bunch on jerks!

Kk7i5MCcd_Jpw40HlYLJmA.text: Absolutely the worst service I've ever had in my life. Service = Horrible  Food = BadNaan = GoodI am in London for work and decided to eat dinner at this establishment after work around 9:10PM on this Thursday. I walked in and the gentleman asked me how many people and I stated one and he responded saying they are full. I pointed out EIGHT open tables I could see and he stated they were all reserved and asked me if I wanted take out. I was unhappy about this but it was late, raining and the place was reviewed well so I decided to take him up on the takeout. He asked me to take a seat at one of the open tables so I did and I then witnessed 3 groups of 2-3 people come in, without reservations, all get seated. I then asked again if I could just eat at the table they had already seated me at and they refused once again. I kept my spirits high hoping the food would be worth the pain however the Paneer Tikka Masala was just as bad and super sweet! I will say the Naan was solid however it did not make up for everything else. I hate to say it but it was almost as if they were being racist to Indians. Really weird experience since I was born and raised in America and there for work. This really caught me off guard since the entire staff was Indian. Felt like I was in Pete from Remember the Titans trying to eat at a restaurant that's racist.Never going back to this place and yes this is my first review EVER and I've been using this app for years.

Qfrus2U5-p-purmKN6ElMg.text: Fantastic! First time having Indian food but Indian City made it a great experience. Chicken tikka masala and chicken tawa were the highlights of the meal. Garlic nan was good too. 4 people were 67£ or a little under 100$, a great value in London!

ueBpV_2H5BkGgxPi2K-fFQ.text: This is some of the best Indian food I've had in London. It is located, quite surprisingly of Fleet street, and looks pretty unassuming. However, the food is magnificent and the service is friendly. This is not your run-fo-the-mill tikka house- you can find a much more diverse range of Indian styles here, and I would suggest venturing off the beaten path.I had the Gosht Tawa, and it was one of the best things I've ever eaten. The lamb is tender and served with a healthy helping of veggies in a rich, complex tomato based sauce which has some tangy hints of lime-leaf. Overall, this wasn't a spicy dish, but watch out for those peppers! A mouthful of these hot little dudes can really make you sweat. Another good choice is the green chilli chicken or spinach. Theres a nice selection of wine as well, and all of it is very affordable. If you love Indian food and aren't afraid to try something new, this is a great place to eat casually or formally.

9I2zaqE4qLAQL_PR8n-wyw.text: Pretty flavorful dishes.  We started with the meat samosas (the 9.95 lunch menu) followed by lamb something and chicken tikka masala.  The meat samosas were tiny, not worth the extra 2p.  The chicken tikka was too tomato-y for our tastes, but the lamb was well cooked and flavorful.  The rice was aromatic and delicious.  The naan was inconsistent, some really thick, other pieces very nice and thin and soft.  Fortunately, they give you about 50 pieces so you can pick the ones you want.  I'd go again if in the area.

e2XdbPEQY_H3ZKkUXNwYJQ.text: The best Indian food I've ever had. They have upscale dishes and specialties I can't find the US. The service was impeccable, and the price was very reasonable for what was served. I went there for lunch with co-workers, and came back the next day for dinner with my wife. It was that good.

g0hOK2sH2_FVnwTAC_S1Dg.text: Was looking for Indian food near the Crown Plaza and walked in here. The appetizer sampler of various meat dishes they serve was outstanding. The chicken tikka was really good and the lamb was ok. Service was great. No complaints.

XYX2WYzdsh9BI6-IBkSvYw.text: This is some of the best Indian Food I've ever had. And I can't say enough good things about the extremely attentive and friendly service. The waiters really took pride in their work. At one point during the evening I said to the table, "I can't find my napkin." then Bam! Like a cosmic genie, one appeared. Truly outstanding.The food is outrageously delicious. All five in our party were doing little happy chair dances about their food and there were no leftovers! my daughter is living in London now and will wrangle an invitation here any day. Glad to see how full it was, too. Everyone happy! Way to go Indian House! You ROCK!

9X0yB-BNhZe5YHt847SlDQ.text: I had the opportunity to enjoy a meal here and I would recommend it strongly.The service and the tastes were top notch.  We shared dishes so I found both the spicy and mild dishes to be delicious.  this place deserves six stars.

ETXxkEyyf-BPKEFGDxOtrw.text: Vindaloo curry to cry for.Excellent food, great service, polite and friendly staff.

5PgNS81hEnelPpxuHMXKAg.text: Really enjoyed my food here. Service was pleasent and food was very authentic. Bagari ghost must try:)

LnMS4qm_EYxB0wWiap-smg.text: Our first time to Indian City as we were traveling from the US on business and were lucky to spend time in London. Found this place was close to our hotel and we decided to try it. After having many Indian restaurants in Cambridge, this one was far superior than any in Cambridge. Food was fantastic and will go again.

ZFLPoUbNQrbtE9_OY1k6rg.text: Very friendly staff and nice atmosphere, but not as flavorful as the other Indian place I tried in London, and definitely not as flavorful as NYC/Chicago Indian places I'm used to. I had a lamb dish that was rated very spicy on the menu (2 out of 2 chili peppers), and it was true to it's rating. I couldn't really taste the meat/seasoning. I like spicy food, but only if there are good flavors to match. It's possible my palette has been too Americanized with less-spicy Indian, I suppose. Also tried an eggplant dish that was a little bland and a chicken dish that was 1 out of 2 spicy-pepper rated. The sauce was a little spicy, but there were also whole peppers mixed in that had the friend I was with sweating and not enjoying the dish. I ate one of the peppers and it was just as hot as my 2-pepper dish. It would be improved if the peppers were on the side or excluded.

H4twGIM6xx_77LsixOD0OQ.text: My wife and I ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala and Saag Paneer for dinner. We had one portion each and could not finish our meal. We were in shock when we had a few bites of the food. To put it plainly the food was crazy sweet. Honest opinion super sweet Indian food is freaking nasty. It's like they just went ahead and added 200 grams of sugar to our meal. Sort of like having a super nasty energy drink in the food. Don't get me wrong. I enjoy trying new things but why in our 30 years of combined Indian food eating experience enjoy having sweet Indian food. There was no real warning this food was super sweet. We added rice and spice to the food to see if we can fix the taste and there was no helping this meal. The rice was sweet as well. But why the heck is Saag Paneer super sweet. It just makes no sense. Did we miss something here? Was this somebody's sick joke. Lets put this in perspective. Sugar is delicious with cake, coffee and tea but not Indian food. They did take the Chicken Tikka Masala off the bill but made us pay for the Saag Paneer. It did get a bit uncomfortable and upsetting when the manager was having an argument with my wife about this. Clearly he needs to learn a bit of manners that the customer is right and just take the meal off the bill and get on with it. I suppose the customer is never right in this country and we just have to grin and bear it. Wine and Naan was ok thankfully. People with diabetic issues beware.

BhTIyM2NDopW73Tju6MekQ.text: Let me add a small dose of reality here. If you are stranded in the heart of the  City on a Sunday night you will notice that your choice of restaurants is slim to say the least. If it is near 10pm and you have crossed out the option of a taxi ride to Brick Lane, you are grateful to find Indian City open. The menu is interesting with a few specials, decor is nice, and service welcoming. 5 stars so far. I like spicy Indian food but don't want to go all out to Vindaloo-style tastebuds annihilation. The conversation with the waiter normally includes placing your spice taste on a scale of 1 to 10. My spice number is 7.5. Well here I was forced too settle to 2 on a scale of 3, no off-menu spice tuning available: 4-stars! Here comes the food, good, tuned to please international guests I would say, which explains the "I fell off my chair" ratings by foreigners. Here comes the cheese nan: 3-quarters from one, and the last quarter much more cooked and obviously from another basket! I pinch myself, thinking this is a mistake which is going to be rectified in the next nano-second. I pull out my phone, stand up, take a picture (with flash) of the Frankenstein nan basket, look  around me, no waiter and no movement! Down to 1-star! I decide to eat the rest of my meal, although with suspicion in my mind that other dishes might have been patchworked from other remains (in hindsight I am pretty sure the rest was fine). At the end of the meal, a complimentary amaretto comes with the bill: back to 2-stars. My discussion with the waiter about the nan finally comes to the admission of a mistake and an offer for a free nan next time (a free meal would have been more appropriate in my opinion). I decide to settle on 3-star as the final discussion was friendly and suitably apologetic and overall the food was good. Might go back if I'm stranded on a Sunday night again, but will inspect the integrity of what lands on my table.

gTr8jydLTbUseiX5BOekjQ.text: We stayed in London for 4 days and ate here 4 times since we all love food and people. The lam chops, spice lam, nans, coconut rice are our all time favorites. The waiters are supper nice and treat us as old friends. Thank you guys. We had a good time in London.

5PhYDjZzJwVdON9oqVJZcQ.text: The staff was so accommodating, we barely waited for anything before someone was asking about our needs. We were inexperienced in the choices, and ordered things a bit spicier than we normally would have, but it was very good. The desserts were simple and quite well done. The amaretto shot at the end was a surprise twist. Loved the atmosphere, and cozy dining. Well done!

A7Q4rek7z5u8FXXz_tBUbg.text: Fantastically spicy. Murgh tikka and garlic naan take away were delicious! Walking distance from St Pauls and the Grange hotel St. Paul's.

gsySis3IW7ss9IoIX5EU0Q.text: I first came here three years ago and at the time it was a simple little Indian restaurant, nothing overly fancy.Since then they completely revamped the place and it is now quite trendy and romantic. The food is really good, especially the naan and it shows that it is made to order. I asked for my chicken tikka masala to be spicy (instead of the standard British, often too mild version) and it was perfect. Make sure you book because it can be quite busy.Pros:- The staff is very professional and helpful.- The food is great, which is always good for a restaurant.- The decoration is tasteful and exotic.Cons:- The room is a bit small and can get noisy.

cVaElBx3Qn2ISHJ48rGovg.text: Great food. Reasonable prices. We enjoyed the green curry chicken Tikka  ..............................

HJgqTRUmHF1TcHdVitYWFg.text: We've been to Indian City three times now, and it's been good every time. Good enough that we brought our visiting friends from Denmark in when they wanted a good Indian meal. I tried the Bhindi Bhaji for the first time here, and the okra is cut extremely thinly (read: deliciously). It's become a new go to side dish for us. I tend to get Vegetable Korma most places I go, and theirs is nice. I adore the hammered silver dishes that so many things are served in. I really want some for my house.This place is quite touristy, but I find it appealing because so many Americans seem to come in. It must be in THE guidebook or something. The staff is always friendly and accommodating. They give a shot of iced Amaretto and a piece of chocolate post-meal, which I find to be clever, appreciated and memorable. It's a great way to finish the meal.We'll definitely be back... many more times.

ORDi7l6FtiMBgjcLDCTS-Q.text: We dropped in at Indian City on a Saturday Night with no reservations. While they were busy, they were able to seat us quickly. The food was delicious and the staff was amazing! The manager was able to answer our questions about their menu to steer us in the direction we wanted to go with our meal. We were even given complimentary after dinner drinks! Do not miss this gem if you find yourself in London.

UW7MLMQBiVlZROYXcIUQZQ.text: 4.5 starsBoy am I glad I found this place! Love it. Beautiful ambiance, very pleasant staff, great service, and delicious food.Saturday night around 8 pm there was a pretty good crowd, but not fl enough for a wait. I would say 75% full at any given time. Very calming, clean setting.The menu is infinitely larger than most Indian restaurant menus, which is fantastic especially because they actually get their dishes right. They know what they're doing.We ordered the chicken balti and the chicken vindaloo. The balti was indicated to be a medium spice level and the vindaloo was indicated to be very hot. Both were accurately described, which is not as common as you'd think. Often times a dish is indicated as spicy and it doesn't even come close. I loved that these were appropriately labeled, but also had flavors other than pure heat that came through.As someone who has a very high tolerance for spice, I did not fine the vindaloo lacking and would not have wanted it any spicier at all. It is extremely spicy let me warn you so not for the faint of tongue. But what's nice is that you can also taste the very tomatoey flavor as well as the other spices. The heat does not mask everything. It's well done.The balti was delicious as well. Milder, but very flavorful. The two of them together were even better. They balanced each other.They have many rice options including a steamed rices, which is plain and not oiled for the more Heath conscious. Honestly with the delicious sauces of the dishes, you can't even taste the lack of oil in the rice so I'd recommend that unless you plan to each rice without mixing it with a saucy dish. Only con is that the rice is so expensive for such a small portion. You really need one per person, so it adds up quickly.We also ordered garlic naan and asked for light butter on top which they accommodated. I loved the fact that they are health conscious in general. When we asked whether the dishes would be oily, we were informed that whenever possible, the chef likes to cut as much oil as he can. We did find this to be a true, which is appreciated. The dishes were substantial and hardy, but didn't make you feel badly after eating them. Perfect balance.The mango lassi was also great - not as sweet as many other lassis, which is a huge added plus. A lot of times they put so much sugar and you can barely taste the yogurt. This was much more balanced and authentic. I'd strongly recommend this place and will be back many times, I'm sure!

foDkJRTUwRYRgBivic69xA.text: The stellar reviews of Indian City do NOT exaggerate! My wife and I live in Chicago and are fortunate to have dined in many fine Indian restaurants, but none exceed the quality and service of this establishment.We enjoyed an outstanding meal that featured garlic naan, Chicken Rogan Josh, and Chicken Tikka Masala -- all delicious! The Tikka Masala was a bit on the sweeter side than other versions I've had, but was terrific nonetheless. The complimentary shots of iced Amaretto were the icing on the cake, so to speak...and given London's notorious high prices, the bill was very reasonable. We highly recommend Indian City -- you cannot go wrong!

R15CZx-RkALwBH9xCLC92Q.text: The reason for this star rating isn't the quality of the food. We never actually got to try the food. We were treated so poorly, we left before they even brought us our water. My parents are pretty picky about eating out, so we've been to countless Indian restaurants around the world. We've never had such rude, biased service before. As we were waiting to be seated, we were chatting with another American group who was equally excited to try the restaurant. We were called to sit first, and before we could even walk in the door, a waiter stood in our way and warned, "Everybody in your party has to order their own main dish. No sharing...minimum one dish per person."We were kind of taken aback. We didn't understand why they were being so insistent about this rule, but we figured they must have some strong policy in place and it wasn't that big of a deal.The other group was seated shortly after us, and they were warmly greeted and seated. They never got the ultimatum that the waiter was so insistent on giving to us. Whatever, we thought. Let's look past it and enjoy dinner.A few minutes pass by. Still no waiter. The group seated after us? Sipping on water and munching on the appetizers they ordered. ...still no service. Finally, a waiter comes to take our order. We start ordering and he cuts us off abruptly because a new group just walked in and needed to be seated. Other staff members were already seating them, but our waiter felt the need to help them.He finally came back after a few minutes. After rudely taking our order, he walked away. We decided we had had enough rude treatment, told him to cancel our order, and we left. Now the twist. All the other diners were white. We're Indian. I'm not a big fan of playing the race card, but I am aware of a certain type of bias that goes on at times. And I think it's interesting when people get mistreated by their own ethnic group. The entire wait staff was Indian, and sometimes Indian people try to show off and "impress the white man." In this restaurant, it was clear the restaurant had certain priorities in mind. Whatever the case, they clearly weren't thrilled about serving us with so many other important customers to tend to. As we were walking out, our waiter approached us to ask if everything was ok. Too late, pal. The damage had been done. We hopped in a cab to Punjab at 80 Neal street and had a GREAT meal with even GREATER service. Indian city, we wanted to like you. But you need to figure out how to take care of all of your customers. Not just the ones you want to impress. Good riddance. Thankfully, there are more than enough great Indian restaurants around London to keep us from having to step foot in your terrible establishment again. And yes, I created a yelp profile tonight in order to write this review at 11:30 at night. That's how horrid the experience was.

wXoGwX5c_Phhq00kLspFzg.text: Excellent food, great service.  The waiters remembered us when we returned to the restaurant for a follow-up visit and gave my children extra candies when they handed me the bill.  The restaurant can get crowded, so try making a reservation to ensure you'll get a seat; alternatively, take-away is available.  The only reason I'm giving them just 4 stars is that the saag paneer and curries were on the sweet side, not as savory as I like, but that might just be personal preference.  I agree 100% on the Vindaloo - that was my favorite dish.

UrS8nHoYTIkUobab5Wsj1w.text: One of the best meals I've had in a while! The set Christmas menu had so many options that you didn't feel like you were making an compromises. They served up a nice quartet of chutneys with crispy flat crackers and the appetizer sampler (samosas, kabob, paneer, fried onions, chicken tikka, and greens) was a great start. Full of flavor that was satisfying to the palette! My main course of prawns in a slightly spicy sauce was great! My wife noted her Chicken Tikka Masala was a bit on the sweeter side but was still very flavorful. The vibe of the place was simple elegance; staff were all friendly and professional; low key and chill. Check this place out if you're ever near the Blackfriars Station in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom

qAXW1uqyocKbG9xA6tajHg.text: Great service and atmosphere here! I had the lamb shank and it was awesome!!! A lot of places are closed around this area on a Sunday, but this one is open. Will be back for more:)

oNM96jkEIwZBR5CL28yUiw.text: Very happy with the food and service.  Had the Christmas menu.  I love the reasonable 12.5% gratuity here in London...unlike the entitled wait staff in the US.

wV_RJtLAe5d8Iku6dti1ug.text: Coming from America, I heard that I had to try Indian food while in London! I then met a nice lady on the train from Paris to London who told me again so I knew it was a must. I actually really have grown to enjoy Indian food over the last few years so I was really excited about this trip. I made reservations on Yelp which is always a nice perk. Reservations were not needed, although it was filling up by the time we left at 9 PM. When my group of 3 got there, we were greeted by the friendly staff, and seated right away. We ordered the tikki masala, chatt, chicken tawa and some side vegetarian dishes. Tawa is a dish that is special to the British culture and that was my favorite. The chicken was tandoori marinated and then stir fried with plenty of vegetables. It had some heat to it, but was not overwhelming. The Tikki Masala was quite different than I am used to in America, but not in a bad way. It was more of a sweet dish rather than savory. Our waiter mentioned that Butter Chicken might be more like what we are used to! Glad we tried it though.Another perk is that they serve 550 ml beers for a reasonable price!

xnFk8zM8Gatlk7Wm82J60Q.text: Small Indian place right by Blackfriar's/Fleet Street. Decor is tasteful, restaurant nice and clean, and they have a very wide selection of extremely tasty Indian dishes, both the traditional, well-known ones, and "chef's specials". Vindaloo is particularly recommendable, if your palate goes to the spicy varieties.The real clincher of this place is the service though, which is very attentive, quick but not rushed, friendly, and overall one of the best service experiences I've had in London. Big recommendation!

SH-azFY-Py51ukXKA4qdHA.text: This little gem of a restaurant is ill-served by it's diminutive street facade. Inside you'll find a classy yet low key venue serving up some authentic and delicious Indian food.My second visit here confirmed the fact the kitchen here pumps out some super-tasty offerings.The wine list is good, and has so far delivered excellent and tasty liquid accompaniments to some truly delicious meals!The staff are excellent, being both very attentive yet unobtrusive in their service.Although I haven't tried too many restaurants in this very 'London City orientated' area, I can say with confidence you'll be more than happy if you visit 'Indian City'. Prices are decent, food is excellent and service superb. As good as it gets!

E9XpNEA8fWro9YTuYke-WA.text: i have eaten in a tonne of Indian restaurants before and i can say that this is a top quality Indian restaurant producing some high end Indian dishes.  These guys use very fresh ingredients and take alot of care with their spices and sauces! My wife and I almost always orders the same dishes so we are a good judge of the Chicken Tikka Masala and lamb Vindaloo at each place we go too (boring yes i know!).  The Vindaloo had a intense heat that was able to creep up on your with each mouthful while still leaving you to taste the rich sauce and beautiful tenderness of the lamb.  My wife's Tikka Masala was a little sweeter than normal but she was a huge fan.   make sure you don't miss the poppadoms starter as well as the garlic naan too...both fantastic.   id like to give this place 4.5 stars but overall i think 4 stars is a fair result.  if you like indian, then you mus ttry this place at least once.

2fVvWU9xNJ7rIlfVmVsnFA.text: With so many good choices for Indian food, you can safely skip this joint. To add to the not so tasty food, the service is really bad. Space constrained, the tables are so crammed that it makes it difficult to have a peaceful meal without someone in the next table speaking into your ears. Tried to give it another chance only to be turned away for lack of space (could have informed us of the wait time, instead of shooing customers away. I was really hungry but it is not too much to expect)

zLtPCoOtRg6NVRZ0Sx1D4Q.text: The food was tasty enough  and will satisfy moderately picky indian food lovers. The service, unfortunately, was TERRIBLE!I booked a table through the Yelp app, and when I got there, they told me in a very terse tone that I should have called in advance, even with a booking, to guarantee a table. I had to wait a bit and then a very annoyed looking person seated me. I really felt bad about it, like I was bothering them. I almost left at that moment but being from out of town and having walked 15 minutes in the cold to get there, I did not want to start exploring the neighborhood for another restaurant.The food was OK, if a bit on the sweet side for a tikka masala. The aubergine side dish was delicious.The ambiance is VERY noisy and busy, so not great for a romantic or introspectif dinner.Overall I cannot recommend this place given how they treat their customers, even if the food was decent.

FRMUFd7Dikr-nchKnTlzlg.text: Had a post boxing day holiday meal here.One of the cities great quality Indian bistros.I had chili sea bass which was outstanding even with the task of picking thru and dining out the bones.Holiday menu featured fixed dining experiences with 4 courses for 25 quid a person. I found it to be an outstanding experience and full spread of food for the price as it included a mixed tandoor grille platter, bread, rice and a side dish curry.Haven't tried it outside of a holiday weekend but would go again if in the neighborhood.

7TlhAkBwbzVn7XttWhSbyA.text: Darn good chow here at this establishment. I thought the service was excellent too.

AXPBI4SezyR10z-ZE5As_g.text: I have nothing but nice things to say about this restaurant. Our flight got in late last night and by the time we checked into where we were staying most places were closed. We saw that Indian City would still be open for another 45 min so we walked over. When we walked in it turns out because it was a slower late evening they had decided to close up a little early. Instead of just Turing us away they offered to put together a take out order for us. All the staff that interacted with us were very friendly and did not seem inconvenienced by accommodating us at all. That covers the service side, which to me is the more important piece. Now on to the food. I ordered the lamb saag. It was fantastic. It was fresh and flavorful. I liked that it was a bit chunkier than what I'm used to. It had a good kick to it, but not overly spicy. Great balance. My other half ordered the chicken tikka masala. I noticed right away that it had a lovely citrus tone to it. It was a little sweet, but not in a bad way. The rice was cooked to perfection. The accompanying sauces were wonderful. We would recommend this place very highly. Thank you for feeding these hungry foreigners past close time. It was greatly appreciated.

fvkKVyrGrASBsB_d-TWkvw.text: Wow. Super disappointed.  Perhaps I've eaten too many times in India and have proper expectations.  The Somosas had paper thin skin instead of thick flakey crust.  The butter chicken was weak sauce, coconutty with out any rich creamy flavor and instead of large dark tender tandori chicken pieces it was thinly sliced chicken breast.  Just very very disappointing.

g6cxvfnAALChtv60jJuLyg.text: TL; DR: best Indian food in the world for a great price and high-class atmosphere. (I've had Indian food on 4 continents and no idea how many countries. This was so much better than the others it should be a different kind of food.)When you walk in, you think you're about to have a ££££ meal and the ambassador is going to ask you for the time. Maybe James Bond is going to crash the place - it's pretty swanky. The aromas are amazing - curry, turmeric, coriander, and more. The pre-appetizer (crispy flat cake with various sauces) had four distinct flavors, each of which seemed like the chef spent all his effort on.  Very different from traditional Indian fare (which is good even still!).  The mint chutney was our favorite.We ordered Saag Paneer and Green Chicken. The saag paneer came out in a more dry and less blended form than normal, but the flavors were powerful but not heavy. Without the heavy cream, it was a fantastic dish. The waiter then brought me a dish of saag paneer in a more traditional style. He thought I might have expected more traditional, so he asked the chef to make another one - I didn't ask or comment, he just did it to make our experience wonderful. It was. The saag paneer with coconut cream was out of this world. My wife's green chicken was something new, but brilliant. Tender chicken breast filets covered in a flavorful aromatic coriander paste was something new and amazing. The mango coco dessert topped it off. Overall, after having Indian food in 4 continents and who knows how many countries, this was the best by far. So much better, in fact, we wondered if this was a different kind of Indian food. Hands down, the best dinner we've had in years. Thank you!

46w3Zsjeiyh_5zOGHsYWaw.text: One word to describe Indian City would be 'pleasant'; a little bit better than nice but yet doesn't quite leave any lasting impression. Everything from the decor of the restaurant (which includes a simple yet elegant floral and butterfly decoration on the wall with funky cacti in front of very clean mirrors) to the presentation of the food shows that effort has been put into appearance and some style and yet it still all seems to lack some panache; there is no common theme or all-round achievement in any of its features. The juice I had did not taste fresh but was not too sweet either so it served its purpose. The sides/dips for the Poppadoms did taste homemade and appetising. The Aloo Chat Puree starter I had went down well because I was hungry but in actual fact the side salad and the dressing was of a better quality than the wrap itself (which seemed slightly soggy). The garlic naan was fair enough; it had hints of garlic, was a good size and not too oily but not particularly well done either (perhaps a bit on the thick side). The Green Chicken Tikka was nicely sizzling hot, containing a generous portion of chicken with subtle flavours and a decent texture and also comes with some complimenting side salad. The lemon rice was a good portion and an attractive golden colour with some unknown gentle spices within the mix. Meanwhile the duck (which I tried off a friend) was unnecessarily spicy and soaked through. All-in-all from what I experienced, Indian City is largely inoffensive and pleasant but not quite outstanding.

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Green Chicken Tikka and side salad
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Green Chicken Tikka
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom

RLIRysz5B08MLc8WnsnHRQ.text: Great Indian food and good price. Make a reservation because the place fills up quickly.  This restaurant is a great night and had candle lit tables.

cwupE6bhat70E2OMgoh5FA.text: Londoners are spoiled. Outstanding  Indian food in the world is common place here and Indian City definately delivers. Hubby and I were staying at a hotel around the corner and made our way into this gem of a find on a whim.From the front entrance the restaurant seems small and it is but makes up for it with big taste. We  ordered the lamb tikka, Aloo Gobi and Channa Masala all if which were delicious.Dinner was a little on the pricy side since evrything and we do mean everything is priced ala carte (£3.25 for naan but can one complain when the food is excellent) but the lunch menu looked quite affordable with 1 and 2 course meals priced at £7.95 & £9.95 respectively.

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Lamb Tikka
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Aloo Gobi, rice and Channa Masala

NSyQOjpzD7HMiB8JDVcHlQ.text: Found this place on yelp and was not disappointed. The restaurant interior was very elegant. Everything felt very upscale and the service matched. Every person was so kind and thoughtful- opening the doors for us and making sure to say goodbye as we were leaving. Plus the food was delicious! Lots of good spices and flavors. Everything came out very quickly as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom

sFuTQvpF_OldNy8GszRFmQ.text: We chose this restaurant for our last night in London. We had eaten at Punjab a few days earlier and loved it. Unfortunately, there was not a single dish here that we liked. My family is Indian so perhaps we wanted something more authentic. The chicken tikka masala was super sweet. Everything else (saag paneer, channa, daal) lacked salt and had odd flavors. I think the daal had cinnamon in it which was very off putting. My children, who love Indian food and eat it several times a week, ended up eating bananas in our hotel room after. It is a nice restaurant with a good ambiance, slightly formal. There were no other children there and it is lit with candles. The majority of customers appeared to be locals and businessman. However, the food is not authentic and has been possibly altered to suit the local palate.

Wkg9plAnL729_rK64SmsvQ.text: This place was super close to my hotel. I had the lamb tika for an app...great!  Naan, rice, and butter chicken for dinner - all quite good.  And as discussed in other reviews, all a la carte. The butter chicken was sweeter than I'm used to having, but not overly so, just different.  Service started out great but fell off towers the end of the meal. Pricing was as expected.

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken goodness

UsbDldWZfLyM7ACG6yEcNw.text: We arrived late at the Crown Plaza next door and set out to find some food at 10pm. This was the only place open and it was crowded and very loud. The staff was on the spot and had us a table for two within 5 minutes. Despite the crowded room they were very attentive and quick to deliver everything. They poured our wine for us and treated us like we were the only people there. The normal menu was off and they had a special Christmas menu. It was pricey, and it was some of the best Indian food I've ever had. The butter chicken was absolutely perfect, and there was an abundant selection of appetizers to enjoy along with several chutneys and sauces.

ITNmAv7K6kaJr7tCokrjOw.text: I went to eat at Indian City for the first time with 3 other people. We had been walking for some time and were very hungry. FYI yelp says this place opens at 5:30 pm but it opens at 5:45 pm.I had a spicy duck dish which I really enjoyed and those that I ate with had other items off the menu not marked as spicy. I agree with other reviewers that the nonspicy dishes seemed fairly sweet as compared to what I'm used to.The food was flavorful and a good time was had by all.

26iKcqpmZegqP3_X_txxZg.text: I enjoyed my meal. The saag was quite good, and "medium" spice was appropriately spicy. The chicken tikka masala was a little disappointing: it was sweet and had an overwhelming nutmeg-like spice. The staff was excellent.

FnK91mo_kIhaGIHwH2rkdQ.text: Delicious,  nicely spiced food in a very pleasant space. Lovely professional wait staff.

7OLKCEcKiDZOfE-hq2y7Kw.text: This is a place you visit for its delightful service and pretty ambiance. Nice wine list too. You'll be in a great mood while in Indian City - no doubt. But while the food is good (and portions are huge and pleasantly priced), it could be seasoned better. Maybe with salt? Not sure, but it was missing a little something. That won't stop us from returning - it really is a happy, lovely place where you can feast like a king - but definitely opt for dishes described on the menu as spicy or complex; otherwise, you may find yourself asking to pass the salt.

mXz6t0uNuj_QGwnmmvSkWw.text: Headed here and the doors were locked at 10:25 with other customers inside.  Why say you're open till 11:00 if you're not?

hUr5hk1pxjTXK7S-LtcPXw.text: Went there during a business trip. The ambiance and service are very good. Prices are pretty reasonable as well. The chicken tikka masala is just OK; I wouldn't recommend it. In fact, if that's what you are after, don't go here unless you like an unusually sweet version. The mango pudding is fine, and it's sweet. It reminded me of the pineapple upside down cake. I wish I'd ordered something else there because apparently, other stuff is good there.

nmiZquRxoQkDWhti0OTMrQ.text: The food was average at best and they overcharged us for appertizers without letting us. I won't eat there again.

SXkjKK01Q0hcdWZYwCXEMQ.text: This restaurant is my favorite Indian place in London.  The food is always perfect.  The staff are always attentive in this somewhat tight spaced restaurant. Try the Shrimp vindaloo.  If you like spicy, then it is for you.   If I find a fault, it is that it is usually 5 degrees too hot. If they get better air circulation it becomes a 5 star

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Yum. Indian beer and food.  Perfect

bo4cFf2H4z3NqzwBMjc2PQ.text: I have visited here many times because this is near my office. Nunn is usually brilliant but sometimes too crispy. Staters are looking great and gorgeous, in particular I like onion bahge. Main dishes are also yummy, only thing I don't like is chicken tika Masala is too sweet.

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom

vXFthEciWXErFVHNxaPGeg.text: I'm giving this review based on all the experience I was able to have with the restaurant after trying to eat there not once, but twice in a day.  The first time was for lunch, we got there 45 minutes before the clearly posted end of their lunch hour, and the restaurant was completely closed.  We were a little sad but thought c'est la vie, we'll come back for dinner.After seeing a show that evening, we walked a mile and got to the restaurant *1 hour and 5 minutes* before their closing which was marked clearly on the door.  The door again was locked but this time the restaurant was 2/3 full inside.  When we waved a man down he tried to shoo us away with hands like beggars.  When we kept waving he came out and insisted they had closed because they were "out of food".  You have 30 curries on your menu, there is no way you ran out of them all - there is no way you ran out of *rice*.  You were not "out of food", you wanted to close over an hour early like you had for lunch - the lie just made it worse.  We hopped in a cab and had fantastic Indian food at another location.I do not write reviews like this, I don't think I've ever written a review where I wasn't able to eat the food before.  This was amazingly frustrating and the staff was beyond rude.

eIsb7bgAajBVbgawCir21w.text: London has some really good Indian restaurants and this is one of them.  Started with a nice poppadum for the table which they charge £.95 per person for.  Chicken tikka masala was excellent as was the chicken xacuti.  Amazing flavor and blend of spices.  Saag had great flavor but the paneer was not that great.  Service was attentive and prices aren't bad.  Note that 12.5% gratuity is added to the bill.  Will definitely be back to this place and recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom

2jeKyXTvTqPZPI6_ordL3g.text: horrible hospitality ... went in on a sunday evening and asked for a table for 1 , the host said the restaurant was full just as i left i saw 2 couples go in separately.appalled by all of this , looks like single folks are not welcome here

h06trITxsHTglnOWKQySGg.text: When I tell people the food in London is good, they don't believe me.  However, that's because they haven't been to Indian City.  A quaint little restaurant with seating both on ground level and in the basement. We were lucky that they were able to seat us for a table of two without reservation, but I wouldn't wing it the next time.  And Indian City is worth the effort to RSVP. Service was excellent; decor was tastefully done.  The food is delicious.  We overheard the table next to us that they enjoyed the food and experience so much the night before that they made a reservation for the next night.  Now that's saying something in a city filled with numerous choices for great cuisine!

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Complimentary amaretto at the end of the meal. Yummy :))
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Lemon givre

5lQYuAG_epnwq9Thotlk6w.text: Placed in a pretty neat and convenient location. Great ambience. Good menu and prices. That's where all the good things end. Pretty bad and rude service staff.

_h7F_iMnp_b9DckMzC6bgw.text: First night exploring London and this was one of the few options that was open past 11. The staff were extremely friendly. Sat down ordered our food and got in and out very quickly. The food was delicious!

WZMgREYraUajnUihzvBcBQ.text: Outstanding tikka masala with fried rice and potato bread.  You can't imagine how good this masala is .. rich thick creamy flavorful.  Just so good you have to each drop.  Chicken awesome.  Service was very good, fit for a king. So recommended.

dzUpRV65LVngtdPxndLk0g.text: The staff was amazing, the Restrant was beautiful and you can dress casual nice. The starters that we had was the king prawn purée so rich and creamy really a great dish. The waiter recommended the green chicken tikkia which was neither of our favorites. The chick was not tender and the flavors were lacking.Dinner course we had the Maas tomato Zol which is monkfish cooked in tomato and traditional curry sauce which I thought was epic but wished we where warned on to order more rice or naan to eat it with. The other dish bengel fish which I believed was lacking. All in all this is my second Indian food restaurant in London and if area I would consider coming back

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom

SIpTIjaaxMr0z6r-a2ZRTA.text: Tasty food, attentive service, nice and cozy ambiance and reasonable price. What else do you need to know

cuU7o5fSoBQzRmlATT1b1Q.text: As others have mentioned, the service will surprise you.  It is unexpectedly formal but attentive. (A detail that I found very pleasant) Someone will most likely greet you and ask about reservations.  Don't be alarmed.  They will still seat you rather quickly at lovely candle-lit cloth-covered tables.The food and beverages are flavorful and well-portioned. (We enjoyed every last bite!)The rice which comes with nearly all the dishes (if you don't opt for naan) is particularly aromatic.  I found myself thoroughly impressed by just their side dishes!This is a great date location.I couldn't see myself revisiting this place with friends but I would love another special evening here.  The ambiance was honestly just too cozy and romantic (and sometimes formal).

photos.caption: Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Lychee beverage
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Indian City menu and table setting
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom. Indian City menu

hFeoQSb1u14xlOxnjbns1w.text: Bad experience! Don't try!We try Indian food very often. This place was not even worth trying. Not to mention the low class and the worst behavior...Stay put for my recommendation for Indian Restaurants in London...Cheers

D6Noavu-cajFIgQlNoGAOw.text: This is a phenomenal hole-in-the-wall. If you want great Indian cuisine, London has it, in fact, I've met Indians who have told me London has better Indian food than Mumbai these days - though I can't substantiate that claim, I can only say Indian City can serve up a mean dish. Totally packed on a friday night, we didn't have reservations but were informed there would be roughly a 1-1/5 hour wait. We decided to go to the pub next door for a few drinks and wait. It worked out great. Going back to Indian City a couple of hours later, the manager welcomed us, stating he didn't think we would come back, and wished he had a better located table for us, it was near the main walkway, kind of high traffic spot, but we were fine with it. The lighting was mood-lit, and the service was attentive. The took our coats to the cloakroom, and we began with Tandoori king prawn and two Cobra beers. The beer was served ice cold and the prawn was melt in your mouth amazing. The creaminess, blended beautifully with the spices, and the soft texture of the prawn the perfect pairing.The manager was very helpful when asked for assistance on picking our entrees, and really helped us narrow down our choices based on our spice and flavor preferences. For our entrees, we opted for Chicken Rogan Josh and Chicken Dansak with pilau rice and garlic and peshwari naan. Everything was out-of-this-world delicious. Flavor factor was at the highest level, plenty of chicken to sauce ratio. The naan was soft in the middle and crunchy at the edges, with garlic and cilantro covering the buttery bread. The manager and server checked in on us multiple times, even though he had much larger parties and a very full restaurant, we appreciated his attentiveness. For dessert we ordered a coconut and mango pureed sorbet, which I can't recall the name of the top of my head, which as expected was delicious, beautifully presented and perfect for cleansing the palate after a great meal.The restaurant was impeccably clean, the busboys constantly removing plates and changing table cloths, not to mention it didn't smell of strong curry when we walked in (which is notorious and sometimes overwhelming in Indian restaurants). The decor was lovely, and the beautiful copper leaf chandelier above us was exquisite. We left extremely happy and will most definitely visit again when in London.

xL1FoXtQefm3aFQy2xFKbQ.text: Family felt like having Indian food so we headed here after seeing it was within .1 mile of our hotel and had strong ratings from Yelpers (you guys are awesome!) Restaurant is very formal with the wait staff all in whites, but the atmosphere is cozy and personnel are attentive and friendly.We loved the korma chicken, sag paneer, and sag chicken. We liked the tikka massala chicken but not as much as the dish by the same name at our fave Indian restaurant back home, but admittedly this is strictly a personal preference and probably biased taste buds. We'd order it again. Naan bread was also perfectly done. Very nice!

bpBof7SA8Fcfh0VsyMvG_Q.text: If anyone thinks this is Indian food then you don't know what Indian food is. Butter chicken tasted like sweet khorma. Bhindi had no salt whatsoever. No idea why it was crowded. These guys should be kicked out of London where there is so much good Indian food.

hfMRrzClS8owUvXi5ZtqwA.text: The food gets 4 stars.  But they lose one star for blatantly and aggressively trying to get customers out so they can close up early.  And they lose another for arguing with customers about what they ordered.  If you mess up an order, fix it.  Bottom line, a little service training for the waitstaff is in order.

qvsX4Wl3_86szUNwU6Qvuw.text: All of the dishes we had were excessively sweet, even when we asked for medium spice, they tasted similar to puréed squash or pumpkin with coconut milk. The meat was good the service was amazing. Perhaps Indian food in the states is just different.

QQWbdWO1d4EYpOPmHwb3kQ.text: This was an unexpected dining experience. Based on the price and other reviews, we thought it would be a more casual experience, but we were greeted by a server asking if we had a reservation, then looked around to see white table cloths and a higher end setup.The service was pretty good, but the food was on the bland side. I've had lots of Indian food, and even other Indian food in London, and found much more flavorful dishes on the East End (around Brick Lane Market is my favorite area for Indian).That said, everything was fresh and the servers were attentive.

dKRR6PYHPoLhGDeD1FRGcg.text: Very interesting Indian food, some tastes that we weren't familiar with. Service was above average and the place was clean and really nicely done.

8O_I3VkSeiX3gj_NDS0tAw.text: Finally got a table here after 3 tries...it was well worth it!!  Visiting London from Houston, Texas and figured I needed to try Indian food while here--this place had good reviews and was close to my hotel.  Turns out I was very impressed!!  Probably the best Indian food I've ever tasted. Amazingly delicious!!  I recommend the chicken tikka masala with rice and garlic nann...your won't regret it! Classic Indian dish and oh soooo good here!

Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian City - London, United Kingdom
